id: PADI Open Water Diver Course-New Zealand Sea Adventures, 9 Marina View, Porirua - Mana-Event Finder
name: PADI Open Water Diver Course
venue: New Zealand Sea Adventures, 9 Marina View, Porirua - Mana
description:
PADI is by far the largest and most popular Scuba diver certifying system in the world and for good reason. Courses are fun, safe, relevant, and packed with excitement! No matter what country you are in, your PADI qualification will be recognised.

The practical part of your Open Water Scuba Diver course takes just four days! During the first weekend, we make it very easy and convenient for you with our on-site dive pool (the only one in the Wellington Region). Our pool is where you learn to dive, so we can go at your pace, no matter how long it takes. During the first weekend, you learn and practice all the necessary dive skills. Once completed, you will be ready for the sea dives.

Once you are a certified diver, you will receive an eCard on your PADI App showing your qualification – and any PADI Dive Centre will be able to confirm your certification on-line. You will also be qualified to attend the PADI Advanced Open Water Diver course, and our regular Dive Days.

We want to make your diving safe and enjoyable. Welcome to the exciting world of Scuba diving!

If you have any questions please call, email or stop by our Dive Store.

Kind regards,
Tony Howell
PADI Course Director
Tel: 04 233-8238 Email: nzsa@scubadiving.co.nz Web: www.scubadiving.co.nz
9 Marina View, Mana, Porirua 5026


PADI Open Water Diver course at a glance:
•Digital theory: Open Water Diver eLearning Course (allow 8-14 hours)
•Practical: One weekend pool training, one weekend with four sea dives
•Options: One-on-one or unscheduled dates – additional costs apply.
•Start Time: Please be at NZ Sea Adventures by 8.30am daily.

Location:
We are located at 9 Marina View, Mana, Porirua; just north of the Paremata bridge on SH1. Look for the big yellow building. Check our website for location.

Prerequisites:
•Be at least 10 years old (special conditions apply for 10 and 11-year-olds)
•Be able to swim 300m (no time limit) and swim/float for 10 minutes.
•Be medically fit to dive. Check the Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire. If you answer YES to any of the questions or have any doubts, a visit to your doctor is required.
•Elearning must be completed before your pool training can begin.
•Complete the RDP Tables Quiz and Exam if you don’t have a dive computer.

What to Bring:
•Completed Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire.
•If Under 18 years – bring a Parent or Legal Guardian to sign your forms.
•A pen, swimming costume, towel and a snack for the breaks.
•Any personal dive equipment you wish to use.
•The $450.00 balance of your course fee.

Cost:
•Scheduled Open Water Diver Course Fee: total is $750.00; deposit is $300.00.
•Includes: PADI eLearning Course, Dive Gear Rental, Pool Sessions, and Sea Dives. Rental wetsuits are available in stock sizes only. Other sizes are available for purchase. Made-to-measure options can be ordered and purchased
•10% off all in-store purchases during your course. Does not include packages.
•$20 off your course fee for every person you get to sign on with you.

When:
Our PADI Open Water Diver Courses are scheduled year-round. See our online calendar for scheduled course dates or ask in store. Booking early guarantees your place and price.
Looking for different dates or smaller classes? Ask about our one-off course options. Let us know what you need and we will do our best to help (conditions may apply).

Booking your course:
•Course bookings can be made in-store, via email, online or over the phone
•The deposit of $300.00 secures your place on a course and purchases your eLearning course.
•Deposits are transferable to another person but are not refundable.
•Elearning courses, once redeemed, cannot be transferred.
•Before we can send you the eLearning link, we require your full name, date of birth, a valid personal email address and phone number.
•Your course balance is to be paid before we can begin your pool training.

id: Visual Journalling - Drawing for Mindfulness-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Visual Journalling - Drawing for Mindfulness
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
Learn how to use drawing and mark-making for visual journalling, to draw out your inner guidance and resources, and bring a creative form of wellness into your daily life.

Lara Phillips, a creative facilitator trained in Interactive Drawing Therapy, will guide you through simple practices that open our subconscious; a resource we can all tap into, to help ourselves.

Note, this is not therapy or counselling rather a self-care tool that you can integrate alongside other wellbeing practices, such as journalling, walking or meditation.

No drawing skills required, this is more mark making not art making.

Each week combines a mix of guided drawings (where you follow cues), practices with others in the group, and self-guided drawings, using knowledge and tools you can take away.

Week 1: Ground
Learn what sits at the heart of this practice, and how to access your subconscious to draw out what it is you need.

Week 2: Wonder
Explore techniques with others in the group, to learn the power of open cues and different ways to listen to your inner voice.

Week 3: Play
Experiment with different ways of playing with your drawings, to stimulate the subconscious to guide you.

Week 4: Self
Apply your knowledge from the workshop to develop self-guiding skills to continue drawings at home.

What is provided: All necessary materials are provided. This includes A3 paper and coloured crayons, as well as printed resources with guiding cues.

What to bring: (Optional) Any preferred journalling materials of choice, such as large journals, coloured markers or coloured pencils. Feel free to bring an A3 folder/case/wallet.

Homework will be offered to help integrate the practice with your personal life.


Sundays, 11 am - 1 pm, 20 July - 10 August.

id: Pelvic Power Workshop-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder

venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Pelvic floor muscles become weakened, often after childbirth, and can cause incontinence, constipation or frequent urination. These Feldenkrais Method® techniques will help you regain muscle efficiency and tone. For women only.

Description
Apart from assisting with supporting internal organs, and controlling elimination, the pelvic floor is an important part of a woman's overall stability and posture, so you will gain improvement in this respect as well. You'll learn far more than conventional pelvic floor strengthening.

You'll learn to differentiate different parts of the pelvic floor, and also how the pelvic floor functions in conjunction with breathing and spinal movements.

By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
-Recognise the anatomy of the pelvic floor, where the muscles are and how they work
- Coordinate the pelvic floor muscles with breathing, and with the spine, and recognise its role in overall good posture
- Discover what habits you have which work against your pelvic floor muscles working well
- Practise exercises designed to help you rehabilitate and strengthen your pelvic floor

Please note that instructions are given verbally rather than by demonstration, so good hearing and understanding of English is required. For women only.

Tucked away, this hidden gem is the perfect spot to rug up in your Christmas sweater and woolly hat (spot prizes for award-winning attire!), sip on a Greytown Distilling Company Gin Mulled Gin, and soak in the warm glow of twinkling lights. The Lunch Society is a quarterly ladies’ lunch event designed to bring together women in Wellington for networking, entertainment, and philanthropy.

This event is all about bringing together like-minded individuals to connect, learn, and share in a vibrant and welcoming atmosphere. Expect an engaging guest speaker, valuable networking opportunities, and plenty of moments to inspire you.

Settle in for a beautifully curated experience featuring:

• A powerful keynote by Katherine Rich on Breaking Barriers, Building Bridges: Women Shaping New Zealand’s Future
• A delicious two-course set menu and a refreshing welcome drink on arrival
• An exclusive goodie bag for every guest + spot prizes

Whether you're a returning guest or joining us for the first time, you’ll be welcomed into a warm, inclusive space that celebrates women, ambition, and community. Come to be inspired, stay to be part of something bigger.

venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
For those who have done Spanish Introductory 1 (16 hours) or have equivalent knowledge (e.g. who may have picked up some basic survival language through travel).

Outcomes:
By the end of the course, you'll:
- Have an improved understanding of, and ability to use more successfully, the material from the previous course
- Have some improved ability to express yourself in basic Spanish
- Have some understanding of present tense irregular verbs, and be able to use some of them correctly
- Understand how comparisons are formed and be able, with some success, to use them correctly

id: Raising Great Kids In An Overindulgent World-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Raising Great Kids In An Overindulgent World
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Parenting today delivers unprecedented challenges – are you wondering what went wrong and somehow ended up living with a child you don’t recognise as should be belonging to you? Get a new perspective, an easy-to-understand model to follow and tools to help you to raise likeable and respectful children in an age of over-indulgence.

This workshop will be a confronting one that will expose you to the risks that children face in this modern overindulgent world. Many have become used to being the constant centre of attention and are unable to delay gratification and aren’t competent in everyday skills.

They have few self-care skills and skills relating to others, can’t take personal responsibility and don’t know what is enough or what is “normal” for others – these children end up having a difficult time of it in life and you will too.

You’ll take away new insight and knowledge plus strategies that you can apply that very night to help your child to be a responsible, likeable and respectful person.

By the end of the session, you’ll be able to:
- Reflect on the current context parents are faced with today
- Find the relevant research
- Practise the parenting tools and discuss the model
- Know where to go to get support

Aimed at parents, grandparents and caregivers of children of all ages.

Presented by Madeleine Taylor.

venue: The Thistle Inn, 3 Mulgrave St, Thorndon, Wellington
description:

Swing clarinetist Oscar Lavën, guitarist Adrian Jensen, and double-bass raconteur Robert Henderson are "Les Tripes" (french for "The Guts") ; a hard-working interpretation of the irresistibly heart-pumping film-noir sound of Django Reinhardt's Quintette du Hot Club de France. id: Tuesday Jewellery-Making in 8 Weeks-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Tuesday Jewellery-Making in 8 Weeks
venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
description:
Our popular weeknight classes are the best way for beginners to get into jewellery making in a lively, warm and friendly environment. It starts on Tue 12 August and runs for 8 weeks until Tue 30 September, 5.30-8pm.

Beginners will focus on cabochon stone set ring. The stone setting process teaches you many fundamental techniques in one project!

We start with basic ring making in copper or brass, students will learn measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting and soldering.
Then we move on to making a practice ring set with a cabochon stone (cabochon means it has a flat bottom and a smooth domed top).

Once your first setting is completed you can move to working in silver and produce another stone set ring with more interesting design elements.

Advanced: Chain Making and other projects.

Please see the link on the Regular Classes page for more detail on course content.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, up to 8 grams of sterling silver, an extra $8 for stones and fine silver and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals and materials are available for purchase in the studio.

id: Pocket Shrine Workshop-Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Pocket Shrine Workshop
venue: Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington
description:
Join us for a relaxed, drop-in style workshop where you’ll craft your own pocket shrine. These miniature altars are made inside small tins and can be dedicated to someone or something meaningful to you. It could be in memory of a loved one, in honour of a favourite artist, pet, place, or even a whimsical nod to the faeries. Anything goes.

Pocket shrines are designed to be carried with you or kept close. You might keep yours on your desk, in your bag, or tucked in your pocket to bring comfort, inspiration, or connection wherever you go.

We’ll have everything you need to bring your shrine to life, including collage materials, fabric scraps, buttons, beads, and more. If you’d like to make a shrine in memory of someone special, you are welcome to bring a small photo of them to include.

This event is part of Takurua Hauora: Winter Wellness, a Wellington event series promoting health and wellbeing inspired by Sir Mason Durie’s Whare Tapa Whā model.

Suitable for ages 12+.

id: The Carol Bean Band-Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Carol Bean Band
venue: Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington
description:
Gate opens 6.30pm Music Starts 7pm Saturday 9 August 2025
The Carol Bean Band play a mix of jazzy blues with a heavy helping of original songs and stylish instrumentation.  Carol Bean – vocals and guitar, Costa Botes – guitar(s), George Packard – upright bass, and Andrew Grayson – drums. 
English-born, California-raised, Carol was influenced by the West Coast music of the 60s and the blues of Mississippi John Hurt, Mance Lipscomb, Lightnin’ Hopkins, and Doc Watson. At LA’s Ash Grove and McCabe’s Music Store she was taught her picking style from a young Ry Cooder who encouraged her to buy the Martin guitar she still plays today. Carol has fronted several bands in New Zealand and recorded 3 studio albums, all on Spotify. She continues to perform at the Wellington Roomfulla Blues Club and with the Kelburn Viaduct Municipal Ensemble Jug Band.
"Carol’s singing is versatile, vibrant, and delivers an earthy quality to her songs." Tom Villano, LA
"… when the mood drops she reveals a more intimate, reflective side…." Graham Reid
"The first three songs of Next Bus Out perfectly set the album up for the interesting  journey that is to come." Nick Bollinger.
Costa is a veteran independent filmmaker with several award winning short films and feature length documentaries to his credit, including the notorious ‘mock doc’ Forgotten Silver, which he made with Peter Jackson. For the last two decades he has created a run of films celebrating individuals who are quirky, creative, passionate, and above all, persistent (Struggle No More, The Last Dogs of Winter, Act of Kindness, Angie, When The Cows Come Home).  These films have included studies of musicians (Paddy Burgin's Wooden Box Band, Nigel Gavin’s Circus, and The Shot Band/ Hobnails @ The Paramount Theatre) because Costa has been a persistent closet musician himself. He has had stints with Chris and Eva Prowse, and Carol Bean's Mount Misery String Band. When he was younger, Costa wanted to move his fingers really fast. Now he just tries to put them in the right place, song by song, and man - does he ever. “Tasty”, “Amazing”, “Great playing”.
See Costa Botes | NZ On Screen & Costa Botes Lone Pine Films (vimeo.com)
George is a professional musician and tutor on Whitireia Polytechnic’s Music Programme, trained classically on the cello. George’s first improvisational experiences were playing ukulele along with the Rolling Stones, John Mayall and The Band (in his bedroom).  With little market for improvisational ukulele he took up the double bass.
George enjoys playing in bands that push the envelope and give expression to the human soul. He has played extensively in many Wellington groups (including currently with the Rag Poets band), appearing a number of times for the Wellington International Festival of the Arts, undertaking national tours for Chamber Music New Zealand, and backing overseas artists in New Zealand. His playing ranges from classical to jazz, to Latin, to ethnic fusion to Americana and country. He believes - at a fundamental level - that music is about human beings making sense of the world and themselves, and about helping heal the world.
Andrew is also the drummer for the band Ghostplane (Beneath the Sleepy Lagoon; Panther Valley Country Club (Arch Hill Records), which includes Phoenix Foundation members). Not only has he joined our team, but his passion is surfing - so let's say he's the youngest and the fittest.
Not for profit, supporting our dedicated musicians. Suggested donation $30
Come along and enjoy this gig in our special space, up close and personal.
Teas, Coffee and Snacks provided. You're welcome to bring anything you'd like to eat or drink.
Parking available in the Coupon zones of Upland Rd & Glasgow St free after 6pm weekdays, and free all through the weekends. The Wilson Carpark at the top of the Cable Car charges 24/7.

id: Elton John vs Billy Joel *NZ Tribute*-Copthorne Hotel & Resort Solway Park, 246 High St, Solway, Masterton-Event Finder
name: Elton John vs Billy Joel *NZ Tribute*
venue: Copthorne Hotel & Resort Solway Park, 246 High St, Solway, Masterton
description:
NZ’s Award-winning hit tribute show “Elton John vs. Billy Joel” are coming to Solway Masterton as part of their NZ-WIDE TOUR!

Doors 7pm , show starts 7.30pm sharp

After wildly successful sell-out shows across New Zealand, join Cam and Sam for an intimate night out as they wow audiences both young and old performing the greatest hits of Elton John and Billy Joel LIVE! Piano Man, Rocket Man, Uptown Girl, Goodbye Yellow Brick Road, We didn’t start the fire, Bennie and the Jets, She’s always a woman, Crocodile Rock and many many more.

Your favourite Elton and Billy songs are in safe hands with Cam and Sam, these professional touring NZ musicians have performed on live national television, commercial radio and featured in the NZ Music Charts in careers spanning two decades. This amazing Piano Man extravaganza features astonishing costumes, two grand pianos in black and white, a lighting show plus plenty of banter and all the songs you love.

Let's face it, Elton John and Billy Joel require little introduction, their music has provided a soundtrack for generations of loving fans. Englishman Sir Elton John has sold over 300 million records, making him one of the best-selling music artists of all time. He has more than fifty Top 40 hits on the UK Singles Chart and US Billboard Hot 100, including seven number-ones in the UK and nine in the US, as well as seven consecutive number-one albums in the US.

American Billy Joel has sold more than 150 million records and ranks as one of the most popular recording artists and respected entertainers in the world. Joel has had 33 Top 40 hits and 23 Grammy nominations. In 1999 he was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame and has received the Recording Industry Association of America Diamond Award, presented for albums that have sold over 10 million copies.

id: Ngā Tūrua Kiwi Play Space for Under 5s-Capital E, 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ngā Tūrua Kiwi Play Space for Under 5s
venue: Capital E, 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington
description:
Sniff, scratch and burrow at Ngā Turua Kiwi, Kiwi Burrows.

In our latest play activation, whānau can explore themes of creating homes, a connection to whenua, and the importance of conservation in Pōneke.

Imagine yourself as a Western Brown Kiwi as you:
- Wriggle and crawl through kiwi burrows of different shapes and sizes.
- Discover hidden surprises on the forest floor, including crunchy textures, a bouncy seat, and even pests hiding amongst the leaf litter.
- Climb the towering tree to the top of the forest canopy, then slide all the way down to the forest floor.
- Get creative and build your own cozy tūrua burrow using ‘raw’ materials (wheelchair-accessible).

There will be something for every age and accessibility-level, with both high-energy and low-energy play options, a pēpē baby area, and wheelchair-accessible play stations.

This activation is supported by Capital Kiwi Project.

PlayHQ is Nōku te Ao Capital E’s public indoor play space for tamariki aged 0-5.

Open Monday-Saturday, 9.30am-3.30pm.

Ngā Tūrua Kiwi will be our final PlayHQ activation at Queens Wharf, before we move to Te Matapihi ki te Ao Nui, the new Central Library.

Nōku te Ao Capital E is located at 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington. No bookings required, donations appreciated.

id: Ngaio Repair Cafe-Ngaio Union Church, 3 Kenya St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ngaio Repair Cafe
venue: Ngaio Union Church, 3 Kenya St, Wellington
description: Ngaio Repair Café, organised in and by Ngaio Union Church, is part of the worldwide Repair Café movement to cut down waste and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Our local volunteer repairers will look at and try to fix all sorts of household gear: wooden, metal, electrical, electronic, pottery, computer, fabric, toys, clothing, beads, cardboard – as long as it’s small enough for you to bring. One of our volunteers is a guitar repairer who can mend and tune any fretted instruments. Another has an oilstone and will sharpen knives. While you wait to have your item looked at, tea and coffee and cold drink are provided. Children with care-givers are welcome. We have some basic materials on site but if your broken thing needs specific parts (e.g. zip, plug) please bring those along. It’s all free but a gold coin koha is appreciated to help local community need. We open each third Saturday of the month beginning March and finishing November.

id: Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
This course is for beginners who have no prior knowledge of te reo Māori or Māori culture. (NZ Citizens and residents pay $109 with ID, all others pay $199).

Description
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

• Have a basic understanding of the Māori spiritual and natural worlds (mana atua, mana whenua), and our important connections to them
• Identify the sounds of Māori letters and pronounce letter combinations using correct intonation and stress patterns
• Confidently greet people, introduce yourself and communicate basic personal information in an informal context
• Identify and respond to phrases in the classroom including basic commands/instructions
• Confidently describe the day/date, time, and the weather

NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

id: Diesel Jenny x Synthetic Children-Valhalla, 154 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Diesel Jenny x Synthetic Children
venue: Valhalla, 154 Vivian Street, Wellington
description:
Two of Aotearoa’s most rungle hardware acts are joining forces for a mid-winter tour across the country this July. Armed with new releases and a reckless lack of MIDI cables, longtime pals Synthetic Children and Diesel Jenny are packing gear into the whip for a trip up and down the motu. The six-date tour will see the pair serve up their respective dishes in Pōneke on Thursday the 17th of July, alongside ethereal favourite Ekho Laliah.

Via hardware synths and drum machines, Synthetic Children (Te Papaioea’s Celina Goacher) is bringing bubbly synths, auto-tuned vulnerabilities, and sub-rattling beats. Her latest Smooch EP, and appearance on the Big Fresh Collective’s Footmahi compilation, show an emerging fun side to her dancefloor arsenal, following the murky weight of 2023’s Everything’s Perpetual. Donnys worldwide have heralded the new release as a “freshly cooked 3 course meal, served up by Palmy’s premier snack pack herself”. Think wonky hyperpop with plenty of low end.

Diesel Jenny’s (Pōneke’s Josh Finegan) live set will blend brain-breaking breaks with sugar-rush synths and 3D club energy years. This tour will celebrate the inaugural release of Diesel Jenny’s white label series with a rock-solid RUC-exempt two-tracker.

With multiple releases on underground mainstays Big Fresh Collective and Bankrupt Records as ABG, this isn’t the first time Diesel Jenny’s revved the engine.

Ekho Laliah is an Aotearoa based artist who stitches together elements of dream pop, freak folk, and ethereal electronica into sonic tapestries with experimental production as the backbone.

Tickets $15 through UTR or $20 at the door

id: Pottery - Handbuilding Basics-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Pottery - Handbuilding Basics
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Learn how to prepare and alter clay. (Held at Wellington Potters' Association, 130 Grant Road, Thorndon).

Learn how to prepare and alter clay: pinch, coil, slab, extruder and roller use. Understand shrinkage and clay care, joining techniques, drape and press moulding, mark making, slip making and application - as well as tetrahedron, cone and cylinder production

The techniques learnt during the making will provide an excellent springboard to creating a wide array of ceramic objects in the future.

The emphasis will be on learning techniques and honing those skills and by the end of the 8 sessions you will have completed three works which will be fired and glazed.

Pottery courses are held at Wellington Potters' Association, 130 Grant Road, Thorndon. All our courses are scheduled up to a year in advance which means the at times we may need to make changes to the original schedule. Please make sure you check your emails regularly in case of any changes.

All materials included in course fee. For more information about Wellington Potters, click on this link.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Offsite Pottery Courses
Presented by Peter Rumble
$499. incl. GST

id: Pottery: Explore Throwing On the Wheel - 3 Day Weekends Workshop-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Pottery: Explore Throwing On the Wheel - 3 Day Weekends Workshop
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
This workshop is for those who want to spend time throwing on the wheel with guidance.

The first two sessions will be throwing and trimming and the last will be glazing the pieces thrown. Ideal for those who have done an intro to throwing and want to practise, Demonstrations will depend on the needs and interests of the students in the workshop.

Students can explore a variety of techniques - cylinder, shaping, creating plates, vases, cups, larger forms, or two part forms.

This workshop includes a maximum of 5kg of clay to work with.

Teenagers booking this course must be a minimum 16 years of age.

Saturdays x 2 and Sunday x 1, 1:30 - 4 pm daily.
19, 20 & 26 July.

For beginners who have no prior knowledge of Chinese Mandarin. (NZ Citizens and residents pay $99 with ID, all others pay $199).

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:
- Recognise and pronounce some basic Mandarin sounds
- Identify Yes/no questions
- Identify content questions - Introduce yourself briefly

Please note the focus of the course is on oral communication, not writing Chinese script.

8 weeks, Wed 5:30 PM- 7:30 PM
Presented by Mei-Fen Sundgren.

id: Writers on Mondays-Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Writers on Mondays
venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
description:
The poems in Biggs Family Prize in Poetry winner Nafanua Purcell Kersel’s Black Sugarcane can sting and soothe, revealing a paradise despoiled by climate change and colonisation, and celebrating a people resilient in the face of it all. Mikaela Nyman is from the autonomous, demilitarised Åland Islands in Finland. Her first poetry collection in English, Anatomy of Sand, follows on from her climate fiction novel Sado. These two urgent contemporary voices join Tamara Tulitua in a conversation about rising seas, political and personal poetry, the local and global.

Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day, and is supported by the Letteri Family.

id: Intro to Watercolour Painting - 8 week course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Intro to Watercolour Painting - 8 week course
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
This class is for anyone interested in making realistic watercolour studies of the world around them.

We will be covering the fundamentals of watercolour: washes, edges, colour theory, composition, tonal value, materials, lighting, subtlety and simplification.

Each week there will be a new still life to work from and artist examples to take inspiration from. Students can also bring along items they would like to paint.

No prior painting experience needed.

In this course you will:

- learn all the basics of watercolour painting.
- discover techniques to manage the paint
- build your confidence to start working on your own projects

You will need to purchase your basic materials for this course and bring them to each class. See materials list below.

Material list for this course is as follows:

- Paper: A4 Hahnemühle Brittania Matt 300g Watercolour Paper, 10 sheet pack, or any watercolour paper. (100% cotton cold-pressed best if budget allows).
- Paint: Pebeo Studio Watercolour Paint 12 colour set, or any watercolour paint. [Need these 6 colours: warm red (e.g., cadmium red), cool red (e.g., alizarin crimson), warm yellow (e.g., cadmium yellow), cool yellow (e.g., lemon yellow), warm blue (e.g., ultramarine), cool blue (e.g., cobalt or prussian). Optional colours: raw sienna, burnt sienna, and viridian].
- Brushes: 1 size 12 round synthetic watercolour brush with a fine tip (e.g., Da Vinci Fit Hobby brush round 373/12 is a good option). [Later on, a brush set is useful: large round (size 20 or 30), medium round (size 10 or 12), small round (size 2 or 3), ½ inch flat brush, size 1 rigger brush, & detail brush size 0].
- Also needed expression folding plastic palette or similar
- Masking Tape Delicate 12mm
- A soft pencil (2B or 4B),
- A kneadable eraser

Inverlochy students get a 10% discount from Gordon Harris art supplies shop. Materials can also be purchased from Spotlight, Whitcoulls, Paper Plus, Warehouse Stationery, Takapuna Art Supplies.

Watercolour shown on website - Magnolia in Glass, Mark Adams, 1979

Thursday mornings, 10 am - 1 pm.
24 July - 11 September.
